body_html:
It looks like you are using rnn.bidirectional_rnn(). The return type of that function changed from a single tensor in 0.7 to a tuple of three tensors in 0.8.

This explains the type error when using two different versions of TensorFlow.

When running on 0.8, you should probably change the last line of your code snippet to ignore the two new return values as follows:

outputs, _, _ = RNN(self.x, self.istate_fw, self.istate_bw, self.real_length, w_x2h, b_x2h)
body_text:
It looks like you are using rnn.bidirectional_rnn(). The return type of that function changed from a single tensor in 0.7 to a tuple of three tensors in 0.8.
This explains the type error when using two different versions of TensorFlow.
When running on 0.8, you should probably change the last line of your code snippet to ignore the two new return values as follows:
outputs, _, _ = RNN(self.x, self.istate_fw, self.istate_bw, self.real_length, w_x2h, b_x2h)
body:
It looks like you are using `rnn.bidirectional_rnn()`. The return type of that function changed from [a single tensor in 0.7](https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/657f1d987aca211e775acbccf719e67864a0be70/tensorflow/python/ops/rnn.py#L323) to [a tuple of three tensors in 0.8](https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/blob/4b7bc3174ed67b4a0eb1803537c9d00f132e9ae7/tensorflow/python/ops/rnn.py#L373).

This explains the type error when using two different versions of TensorFlow.

When running on 0.8, you should probably change the last line of your code snippet to ignore the two new return values as follows:

``` python
outputs, _, _ = RNN(self.x, self.istate_fw, self.istate_bw, self.real_length, w_x2h, b_x2h)
```
